summary: Former astronaut Jeff Tracy (Bill Paxton) runs International Rescue, a top-secret heroic organization, from his headquarters on Tracy Island. The island also houses the futuristic vehicles created by Ray "Brains" Hackenbacker (Anthony Edwards). But while Jeff is on a mission in space, his nemesis, The Hood (Ben Kingsley), invades Tracy Island. The Hood plots to use the island's technology for evil, and only Jeff's son, Alan (Brady Corbet), can stop him.

reviews.content: It may not be a good film itself unlike the cartoon puppet series. Thunderbirds is a more children's live action film.
I don't know why no-one likes this film. Its really fun, and a great adaptation of the original show. Great Score, nice acting (Mostly Parker) and brilliant thunderbird designs.
Loved it so much good casting

I though that this film would be awful after looking at the trailer and review rating. So I made a bet that if I ended up loving the film that I would create an account on rotten tomatoes and leave a good review. And, here we are. I loved it, watch this film.

If you are a fan of the original 1960s Thunderbird's TV show then this movie is not for you. Somehow they managed to make a film about the International Rescue family without showing hardly any rescuing. They even needed rescuing themselves.

The film starts off well, for all of 3 minutes. We get a very brief intro sequence showing a standard rescue. Then after heading back to Tracey Island they receive a distress call from Thunderbird 5 prompting all active International Rescue members to head off to help in Thunderbird 3. They are then stranded up in space, and I am not kidding on this one, spend 2/3 of the film trapped in space doing practically nothing. Instead of various rescue missions the filmmakers thought we would prefer to spend the time watching 3 children walking around the island avoiding various dangers. 

The film also commits its biggest sin by not including even one remake of the classic sequence where the pilots are taken to their Thunderbirds via various elaborate chair and escalator rides. 

The Actress and character of Lady Penelope are the films only real strong point as well as the actor and character of Parker. The film at least got them both right. But they alone could not carry this film.

For some reason the people behind this film decided that they would make a Thunderbirds film while mostly leaving out everything that made the original Thunderbirds series that classic that it was.

A movie that is true to the original "Thunderbirds" television program, and made for the 7-12 demographic. Most complaints are that this movie is not "Spy Kids", or that it is boring or has bad writing.

This movie is not "Spy Kids", that is true. (And the "Spy Kids" movies are good.)

For people who watched "Thunderbirds" in the 1960s (and who now have grayer hair), yes, this movie will probably not have what you want. But for pre-teens, especially those with some familiarity of "Thunderbirds", it can be a fun trip.
It's a very nice, but i'd say a bit dated, flick

Thunderbirds is a 2004 British-American science fiction action-adventure film directed by Jonathan Frakes, based on the 1960s TV series Thunderbirds üçø 

Oof, this is totally rotten ‚òπÔ∏è
Don't bother seeing it üëéüèºüëéüèºüëéüèº

I liked the original TV show...
God this awful movie doesn't even deserve to call itself Thunderbirds, what was once a beloved children's TV show turned into a complete mess
This movie was very clearly targeting a younger, more undeveloped audience, but I still have some fun with it, and who doesn't like Bill Paxton.
Not really my cup of tea
Not great... terrific soundtrack from Busted, mind.

Waste of money. I could've found a better band down the local train station. Such an insult to the original and even the new cartoons are better than this live action film.
PS don't watch it. Should be called crappy thunderbirds.

This is a bad film, just bad. The filmmaker plays this out like some jokey throw back, but the tone is inconsistent. The characters are one dimensional and you can see why this film went through various directors over the years. Frakes has gone to director jail and I can't say all this is his fault, I'm assuming he was a gun for hire and this was not his vision. The acting is chewy and the ham factor is dialled up to 11, becoming tiresome to watch. A major letdown and just a bad film that has no real redeeming qualities. 10/04/2019

Good movie and that had its funny scenes.

Sadly another underrated movie.

the film is so full of wooden scenes the plot is something that a 5 year old would write this deserves a reboot,Tracy Island looks like a 70's house and they only good thing about the film is Bill Paxton,Sophia Myles,Ben Kingsley and Ron Cook

Universally this seems to be hated but Felix and I both enjoyed it.  It's not really a Thunderbirds movie (which is a shame, the cartoon reboot shows that one would work) as most of the Tracy clan are relegated to be stranded in space for most of the duration.  The movie itself focuses on Alan and as a result has more of a 'Spy Kids' or Mid '80s kids flick feel.  It's all good fun though and no-one is taking anything too seriously.  My 4 year old Thunderbirds obsessed son loved it and basically wanted to watch it again immediately afterwards so it's clearly pleasing it's target audience.
This was a childhood memory to me

The Thunderbirds was one of my favorite TV shows when I was a kid. This movie is a live action version of the 1960s action/adventure Supermarionation puppet show directed by Jonathan Frakes who played Riker on Star Trek: The Next Generation(ST:TNG.)  I always thought Frakes was a better director than actor.  Some of the best ST:TNG episodes were directed by him.  While I think Frakes did a good job of directing this movie I was disappointed to see that this was meant for a younger audience.  I felt like I was watching something on the Disney channel. The main characters were three kids and the adults had supporting roles. The original characters were pushed into the background and the story centered around the three new younger characters.  I would have preferred to see the original characters as the main focus.

That movie was a very funny revisit of a kids show. Made for your inenr child to enjoy. And I did enjoy it. Not the best movie of all times, but by far not as bad as all the trolls male it out to be! If you loved the show as a kid, give it a fair burl.

Aww man, Frakes you're better than this. The same goes for Kingsley but then I'm used to seeing him appear in bad movies. But Frakes man, you directed my favorite Star Trek film and showed real talent. But this... It looks like Spy Kids, only without the sense of fun. And with worse acting. Honestly, how could the original cast of puppets be better actors than flesh and blood performers? Sure, focusing entirely on three kids separated from your seasoned performers for them to play off of was always going to be dangerous, but these kids are remarkably flat even given the circumstances. While the dreadful script is mostly to blame for that, Frakes has to take some responsibility. The "martial arts" scenes would have looked cheesy even in TNG fight scene. Used to working with experienced actors he has no idea how to handle children, and for some reason he manages to screw up the pacing on even the few decent moments the script throws up. Rush rush rush to get to the end. A worthy goal as it happens, but it makes the entire film a real drag.
I give it this rating because i actually liked it as a kid.

Grade: High kind of 2/10 if that makes it any better

Thunderbirds is an adventure remake of the original TV series of the same name and one that destroys it's legacy and systematically kills it dead. It is an awful reworking and one that is just awful, it is worse than bad and who this was made for I will never know. This movie is obviously aimed at kids and even looking at it that way doesn't make sense, it is offending to the kids as well it is just so terrible.

The plot is really crazy and kind of a bit haywire, it just jumps a little too much ahead and never slows down to consider what it is doing, that includes the various changes the film has between camera shots with certain clothing changing constantly. Now of course it is a good old adventure, but the case is it is executed terribly, some could find bits here and there where it could be improved but for me this was a lost case within the first 5 minutes and one I will not remember fondly.

The acting if it even possible is even worse than the story and even the best actors and most experienced can't escape this quagmire of a movie. Brady Corbet our main character Alan Tracy is just awful and is progressively really really annoying to the senses. Big actors like Ben Kingsley and Bill Paxton aren't terrible but still poor and no depth or expertise can they give the roles, not that they can as it is just so badly made. The rest of the cast don't do much to stand out and again I felt with the people involved, it is impossible to impress in such a drab plot.

What can I say positively about this, well, the effects used are not so bad for 2004 the year this came out and sometimes you can kind of think very nice. But even with the effects I have a problem as although they are nice, they are way overused at moments and then put in really silly times, it is as if strategic effects are used to then create some kind of disaster waiting to come.

One lasting hateful thing this movie does is ruin the massive legacy of the old puppet and strings TV series of the 1960's and really shows kids of this day the wrong message, one of silly jokes and silly characters(some of which are completely made up for this movie). I think if you want to respect an old legendary thing then please don't change it because this is altered actually quite a little bit and it could be said too much, the future revamp didn't work and the vehicles are highlights of the randomness this movie brings.

I guess I could say it is well choreographed in the fighting and sometimes it can seem nice, even though some fighting seems overly choreographed so it can be blatantly seen it has just taught to the actor. The title sequence is very nice I'll give it that and the soundtrack from the band Busted is really a big song and one that if played actually in the film as things go on could have drastically improved the kick-ass like factor it sorely needs.

Overall it is terrible and is really really far from being positive, I am equally just as glad this didn't spawn any sequel or with a horrible thought, a franchise. Yes Thunderbirds(2004) is not a good movie and one that although I hope will be remade in the future well, may have to stick to animation to get proper results.

There Is Just No Charisma In The Characters. None Whatsoever. Even Schooled Actors (Bill Paxton / Ben Kingsley) Can't Seemed To Resuscitate An Ailing Script. In Parts, It Wakes You Up With A Bit Of Sky-Rocketing Blast-Off Action..But There Is Nothing More Going On Here. Pity, Because The Series Is Followed Like A Cult Because The Rescuing Is So Exciting..That Excitement Very Much Lacks Here.
A  very good tribute to my childhood and what got me into Airplanes
Just bad, half a star for the mess Bill Paxton and Ben Kingsley got themselves in.

A really forgettable piece of filmmaking that is not worth your time at all. It boasts unmemorable characters, poor acting, wasted talent, tensionless situations, and bad mediocre writing. Throughout the movie, I wished that I would be watching  something better. The child actors bring no good presence on screen and I did not care about any of them. Talented actors Ben Kingsley and Bill Paxton are not given much to do and they were under a poorly written script. The only positives I could name was that I thought the premise was intriguing and if it had been in good hands, it would have been a solid movie and the other positive was that it wasn't a total piece of garbage. There is nothing to recommend here and it was only made to try to make a quick buck from the general public.

full of action the Thunderbirds are reunited and brought to a new generation of thunderfans, although the storyline is crap and not much scenes with the Thunderbirds it never gets old for my mind and It brought a brilient well casted movie to the ones whom loved the TV series and their offspring to bring down the tradition of loving internatial rescue all over again
This film may have pissed off a lot of fans but that's because this is a children's movie, so if you are hoping this lives up to your expectation, this isn't for you.
Only decent thing to come from this was the Busted song.
Not at all a fun time.
It's been a while since I watched it but I remember liking it as a kid. It's somewhat stupid, but harmless fun for younger people.
A corporate money-machine interpretation of a classic serious, devoid of everything that made the original series popular and desperately pandering to the easily-manipulated tween audience
Not the best movie, but it was my favorite when I was 11 or 12 :P

A very bad film adaptation of a beloved TV show. It introduces brand new characters who nobody wanted to see and a messed up story line. However kids will like this film because of the cool spaceships and fighting. I really liked it when I was younger though, infact, I loved it when I was a kid.

An insult to both the 1960's TV series and my childhood, Thunderbirds has none of delightful trademarks of the show, and, strangely, almost no actual rescues. A terrible story and mostly rubbish cast don't help either.
Terrible.

I was surprised by this movie, I liked it more than I thought I would, and I dare say more than I should've. There were more good actors than I expected, It was more intentionally funny than I expected. Is it a good movie? I really don't think so, but if you want dumb, silly fun or something to keep the kids out of the way, you can't really go wrong with Thunderbirds.
Entertaining enough; however it doesn't show the greatness that could have been with a live action feature of the Thunderbirds.

Many of the fans of the original will love it and young boys will find themselves converted, but in reality the acting is mediocre and the script in most parts is thin. Although the fight scenes are comedic and Sophia Myles, Ben Kingsley and Ron Cook bring some memorable highlights.
this film is a kiddie film with the worst ensemble cast
This movie I whatched over and over again
Hammy, silly,  with mis-matched performances, this is strictly for kids. Little kids. Very, little kids.

Just... so bad. Ben Kingsley better have been paid so well for this. I must say though, I get a good kick out of the fact that his villain's name is "The Hood". Who-- no really, WHO?!-- came up with that name?
I watched this so much times when I was a kid

disappointing movie after 32 fantastic, hour-long episodes from the 1960's. i think Gerry Anderson (the creator of the series) would be turning in his grave after this stupid movie. the effects are fantastic, like they should be, but the story-line, acting and ending are corny and badly thought-out

Being old enough to recall the animated puppets in this show when it was a top hit among us 'kids'., this is an up to date movie with real people not puppets and remains true to all the cool things found in the original episodes. "Thunderbirds Are Go!"
My nth time to watch this.  Am I the only one who likes this movie???
good movie. Vannessa Anne Hudgens is hot.

For a film based on the the television series, its surprising how little the Thunderbirds actually appear in the film. Thunderbirds is more of a Spy Kids ripoff without the fun. The only redeeming quality was watching Ben Kingsley try to act wooden faced, like a puppet.....

 Team America comes closer to being like the Thunderbirds, than this piece of drek.....

This film was showing on NRJ12 the other evening and since it√¢(TM)s school holidays we thought that we could let the kids watch it. Now I never saw this, apparently, iconic TV-show from the 60√¢(TM)s so I√¢(TM)m not another disgruntled fan boy, and there seems to be plenty of those, but this film is of little interest for anyone above 9.
 
It√¢(TM)s just plain silly with a nonsense plot although it√¢(TM)s admittedly good enough for a (very) young children√¢(TM)s film. But the acting is plain bad and boring. The special effects are mediocre to say the least. Really young kids probably like it but with the material one could have done something much better which would have appealed to the entire family.
 
My biggest gripe is perhaps that Jonathan Frakes got his name mixed up with this mess. He should have had enough sense to go to red alert and raise shields when whoever dimwit that wrote it came within sensor range.

Now I never saw this, apparently, iconic TV-show from the 60√¢(TM)s so I√¢(TM)m not another disgruntled fan boy, and there seems to be plenty of those, but this film is of little interest for anyone above 9.
 
It√¢(TM)s just plain silly with a nonsense plot although it√¢(TM)s admittedly good enough for a (very) young children√¢(TM)s film. But the acting is plain bad and boring. The special effects are mediocre to say the least. Really young kids probably like it but with the material one could have done something much better which would have appealed to the entire family.
 
My biggest gripe is perhaps that Jonathan Frakes got his name mixed up with this mess. He should have had enough sense to go to red alert and raise shields when whoever dimwit that wrote it came within sensor range.

136800 frames of pure cringe inducing, horrid, dusgusting, childhood raping "film making".  There is no excuse for something like this to be produced.  No respect for the source material whatsoever.  Honestly, if you are going to make a movie bassed on the clasic 1960's Thunderbirds, then make sure you are passionate about that series.  The people behind this obviously were not.  They didn't even get the piolits matched up with the right ship!  It was worthy of self harm and I hope to never see it again.  And what the fuck was up with Thunderbird 4?
aside from some... random cartoony sound-effects, bad editing and what was otherwise just rising questions, it was fun to see... but not very memorable.
this movie is my favorite

What impenetrable, overwrought codswallop this one's turned out to be. Once again, the American's screw up a British show. Thunderbirds wants to be two things at once: a live-action gee-whiz kiddie flick and a nostalgic spoof of 60's England when it swung like a pendulum. The characters were way off and even though this is meant to be a sort of "Prequel" to the awesome TV series, they added characters that didn't exist, maybe to try and make it kiddie friendly. The actors were awful and though Bill Paxton makes an almost credible Tracey, the kids were plain rubbish and extremely wooden. The special effects are nothing new and really dull, boring and a tad over used, and even though the production value is probably the best thing about the film, don't let the intro and music fool you that this is respecting the brilliant 1960's puppet TV series, because it doesn't. When seeing the "Thunderbird's 1, 2, 3, etc etc...it does look good but the nostalgic wears off very quickly. Avoid and stick to the classic TV series. Blunderturds more like...
I just checked it out from the library and I love that movie.
A b****rdisation of a classic TV show which deserved better. Horrible.

Fans of the original puppet series may be divided by this live action transition, as it offers an interesting and detailed take on Tracy Island and its machines, but also a more cartoonish aspect via the actors direction and emphasis on the kids. Despite Ben Kingsleys acting being 'human' enough, The Hood's awkwardly bland and non-threatening. Basically, great for adolescent but dull to older fans.
Enjoyable, id prefer the puppet version.

I remember I asked a friend of mine if he had seen the live-action Thunderbirds movie from 2004 and he said it was rubbish. He wasn't wrong: this was one of the worst films I've ever seen. For those faithful to the original mid-60s puppet TV series, you will not enjoy this embarrassment. The plot is predictable, the acting is poor, the script is unimaginative and the general underemphasis on the Thunderbird machines as opposed to the members of the Tracy family is reprehensible. Granted, Sophia Myles, Ron Cook and Ben Kingsley do provide respectable performances, however the remainder of the cast lack personality and performance. I'm sorry to say that the more I tried to enjoy this movie, the more I actually hated it. Apart from special effects, some decent performances and a cool soundtrack, there is very little to offer here. A huge disappointment and a wasted opportunity.
Well.... I did enjoy it even though it was kinda weird..
Not that bad for a kids film but not that good either
Amazing actors, lost in space...
I watched it when i was kid lol :P

Poor.  Loved the TV series as a kid, but this movie would have been bad even without the disappointment of that comparison.  Meant for kids (I guess that's why Vanessa Hudgens is in it), it seems, but even they might find this empty.  Dull, unimaginative.  Even the CGI is fairly weak.

The presence of Bill Paxton should tell you this is going to be crap.  Ben Kingsley really needs to choose his roles better.  The only redeeming quality of the entire movie is the presence of the stunningly beautiful Sophia Myles, as Lady Penelope.  And she can act too...
Why did they not make more of these? Not the best movie ever but I found it really enjoyable. Is that wrong?
An absolute travesty of a film. At least it is a large, very visible blip on the filmography of the always arrogant Sir Ben Kingsley.
ok i'm gonna be honest. i only watched this movie because vanessa hudgens was in it.however i have come to a conclusion that its not half bad. i would recommend for teens and tweens
Thunderbirds could have been a good movie, all it needed was say something to do with the series or a good script without simplistic dialgoue.
no kid could like this nevermind a adult
Some scenes are good, some scenes are bad

not a bad film and some parts were really cute. I've seen it a few times and no not by myself, but a few times. only once by myself because i had to check it out before someone much younger could watch it. It's a good family film.
The original TV series was puppets and camp. This movie stays true to the original so you shouldn't expect oscar material. The Thunderbirds look great. My favourite was always Thunderbird 2.

Thunderbirds never really connected with me at all, The actors chosen for these roles were quite dissapointing. Bill Paxton and Ben Kingesly are well known proven actors who continue to prove themselves, but Thunderbirds must not have been serious for them, more like a paycheck. Kids may take a considerate liking but adults may think, oh my god, No thank you. So cheesy, pointless even making a film about the famous 60's show of puppets.

Abysmal live action update of the flawless 1960s children's classic TV series.
The vehicles of the original have been neatly updated while staying true to the spirit of the classic designs but oh dear, who decided to put Lady Penelope in a Ford? Sacrilege!
Ben Kingsley has made some terrible movie choices in his time but quite what he thought he was doing here is a complete mystery. Bill Paxton as head of the the Tracy clan is charmless and then there's the insufferable Brady Corbet who seriously needs his face rubbing up and down a brick wall until he learns his lesson
A terrible, clunking script replaces the peril of the original scenarios seen on TV with ham so thickly cut that it almost has a curly tail and trotters.
All but the stupidest child would be bored rigid by this dreadful and  instantly forgettable movie.

I've always thought that most huge box-office flops usually have something to recommend them, but after the remake of Around the World in 80 Days and Thunderbirds, I'm beginning to doubt it. For those not familiar, it's based on a puppet show about a family of astronauts who use state of the art rockets, spaceships and subs to rescue people from various disasters (falling bridges, stricken planes, burning buildings, etc) each week. Well, the puppets are gone (replaced by far more lifeless teenagers), and so is the premise - only one ineptly staged rescue and a plot shamelessly ripped off from Spy Kids without any signs of imagination, wit or entertainment. Young Alan Tracey feels left out of all the rescuing we never see the other Traceys do because dad won't let him play with a real rocket until he passes his exams. Grounded on a beautiful tropical island (some punishment!), his chance to shine comes when the rest of the family - a bunch of identikit bleach-blondes who look like a gay neo-Nazi boy band without a single bit of characterisation between them - are stranded in space and he has to have the day by, er, running around the jungle, making a phone call, firing a hose at the inept comedy relief villains and dousing them in gunk for bad measure.

The good points are few and far between. One of them is that the film is mostly in focus. The other is they all got to go to the Seychelles, which looks nice.

The bad points: where to start? Ben Kingsley's career lowpoint performance? The aforementioned inept comedy relief sidekicks who would disgrace the Children's Film Foundation at its worst? The almost complete lack of action or effects in a $70m sci-fi film? The terrible script, the lifeless direction, the odious moralising? But most of all is the fact that the film is so patronising in every possible way. Forget the life lessons and off the peg sentiment, this is a movie aimed straight at the under-eights by people who know they're making a kid's movie and are constantly talking down to their intended audience, throwing in fifth-rate jokes and routines that would insult most children who had only recently mastered the art of speech. This film could replace being sent to bed early without their dinner as parents' favourite punishment for kids.

The biggest flop in British film history (it didn't even cover the cost of prints and marketing), it's just about watchable if only as an object lesson in how NOT to make a summer movie.

Well, they tried. The actual Thunderbird ships were cool, the red just was ok.
Made me wish the original show was back on TV.
I didn't expect this movie to be intelligent. But was it necessary to make it so boring and offensively bad? Not even the youngest kids would like this.

i don't even know why i'm reviewing this piece of shit...


anyway as a fan of the orignal series done by Gerry Anderson (and an owner of the original 2 theatrical movies) i say this movie had potential with some of the cast and director...but clearly somebody didn't do there homework on the original source material, for in the original Series theyre father (Jeff Tracy) is retired and basically the commander of the organization (which is meant to be a secret one) and alan is the pilot of thunderbird 3 (the rocket) also who the fuck is this kid that's apparently the son of brains? i mean c'mon what the fuck...i could go on about what i found wrong with what little i managed to tolerate of this movie but in the end, Stay Far...Far...Away from this load of garbage and stick to the original 2 films (Thunderbirds are Go! and Thunderbird 6)
has potential...but fails big time

I'm sorry. This is a fail, and that's the whole darn truth. The main character came across to me as big headed, talentless, and a real douche. His (and everyone else's) acting was terrible. I've seen five year olds do better. This movie was a waste, a disaster, and even though the thunderbirds save people, they failed to save the audiences attention.

Me not being a fan of the classic puppet TV show of the same name, I couldn't really say this movie would have been better with the puppets in it instead of this weak cast. Either way, I felt that the movie would have sucked with or without the cheesy puppets. That's saying a lot.

I approached this having no expectations but I was curious to see if this was good enough to hold my enthusiasm, that it did - and having fond memories of watching the TV series on Saturday/Sunday mornings, the movie captured some of its charm, but that's all.
After watching this unecessary remake, I went outside in the rain, threw my hands up to the heavens and cried "WHYYYYY???".

Jonathan "star trek" frakes directed this? Bit odd. Its pointless and a bit of a flip of the bird to fans, which i aint really coz i never seen a full episode. Admittedly the odd burst of cgi action is entertaining in a dumb way but its not thunderbirds really is it? A clear attempt to try and reboot an old property purely in a money making way. The original theme tune is hummable tho. Next theyll try and make team america into a live action film....oh wait they already did -  it was called "GI JOE".....
Thunderbirds is an uninteresting cartoon, with nothing to offer kids of any age.

Jeff Tracy, I repeat Jeff Tracy over. A family of bad actors led by Chet from Weird Science have taken over Tracy Island and are impersonating you and your sons. I request that Alan piloting Thunderbird 3 transport Paxton and these annoying brats to Thunderbird 5 where John will be relieved of duty and this painful to watch brood of bad acting will be left in his place with all communications to Thunderbird 5 being disabled. If possible, could you also send Thunderbird 5 on a one way non-returnable trip through a wormhole. FAB.
Where can I get a pink winged six-wheeler?
Thunderbirds couldn't be interesting to even small children even if it were a cartoon.

When I was a kid, I used to watch the Thunderbirds, I thought the show was excellent, fun and Thrilling. I was a little skeptical about watching this film, as it looked like a kids film, and it also looked like the film makers didn't know what they were doing. Boy was I right. Ths film is Aan insult to the original series, and it's fans. They could've at least made a film that the whole family could love, but instead they made a crap film. With it's child oriented humour, the film is a faillure even by child oriented film standards.  This film was amusing, but it wore off, and the fact that they 'reinvented' the look and style of the original series was just wrong. They could have at least try to make a film that the entire family could love, instead they simply made this film for kids, this was honestly a bad move. One of the reasons why is becase the original fans of the series were born in the 60's and grew up watching Thunderbirds, my dad grew up on it, and he made me watch it when I was a kid. Anyhow, the film is terrible because every actor here seems miscast for the part, the story is lame, and the actors are plainly silly. Ben Kingsly was a joke in this film, not even his talent could redeem such a horrid picture. I really was hoping for something terrific on screen. Instead we were given a total joke of a movie. The nostalgic feel of this film is absent. The only good thing that came out of this film is that it will reiinforce the status of the original series more. Watch the series instead instead of this filth. This is a film that should not have been made.

A blast from the past, definitely.  For those who are old enough, set the way-back machine to the '60's for a marionette show called "The Thunderbirds" of an international rescue family.  That show is the basis of this movie.  It was a show I adored as a child, so seeing the hommage paid to the show in this movie was fun, indeed.  Yes, it is live action, yes, the characters are cartoonish and unbelievable, yes the show is from a kid's point of view so the child knows everything.  Go beyond that, and director Jonathan Frakes does a fantastic job not changing the characters or the ships.  Throw in some suggestive humor for adults and a good cast that evidently had a blast making the movie, and you get a fun trip down memory lane.  Enjoyable.

I rewatched it for the first time since it was in the theater, and for a family friendly film that holds true to the original series, it stands up far better then I thought it would, it doesn't feel like it's almost 6 years old. It does pay the proper respect to it's TV series, and that's a lot more than I can say about a lot of remakes, so it gets a thumbs up as family fun.
Another film my daughter wanted me to see with her. As so often before she loved it while I hated it :)

When is Hollywood going to get that nothing good comes out of making a movie from very old kid shows? I mean, movies like Flinstones who was nothing put a failure and i am not even going to mention the horrific sequel. Scooby Doo is maybe the best of the worst but still something that should have been avoided at all cost, and many many more. For a second i was expecting something exiting, entertaining, lively and fun like for example Spy Kids (which i think is a very good family movie) but unfortunately i got the opposite.

Thunderbirds is a thin, extinct children's movie that has nothing good to offer the people over 11 and specially not the parents. Bill Paxton and Ben Kingsley are both class A actors but unfortunately they are given roles of unexciting stereotypes and I don't doubt this movie put a black stain on their record. The kids are just awful, the acting reminds me of a Disney show that has run its course. Couldn't they have spent a little more time on casting and a little less on the visuals? All of them are irritating and plain boring. The movie may have cool visual effects like a Hollywood movie is made to do but the movie never becomes anywhere near mediocre.

I can imagine the young children under 11 enjoying this but even then it's pretty limited but the rest of us will be checking our clocks every 2 minutes. 

1/5

God this was a stupid movie, really painful and stupid. I'm not really remembering too much of what actually "happened" perse, but I'm sure that the geeky plotline and the stupid jerk of a main character probably didn't click. The movie starts some boring kid as the main character with no real depth, and High School Musical girl is his lover, and an overwhelmingly obnoxious glasses wearer who is supposed to be sympathetic but is so whiny and needy that literally the only moment I enjoyed was when protagonist makes fun of his stutter. And Ben Kingsley does stuff that is mean and has yellow eyes and whatnot, and I can't believe that he won an Oscar and still has time for this stuff...whatever, it's not like anyone wants to see this anyway.
Take it from me, this was BAD.

As a kid, I enjoyed the t.v. show.  I try not to view films with to many expectations, but I may have with this one.  I did not expect puppets, nor some cinematic blockbuster, however this films greatest fault is that it is to campy, even for the original puppet show. It was clearly not intended for my age group, as it focused more towards the teens (the main story line revolves around one of the younger Thunderbird members).  This is a bargain basement film, which you should spend the littlest amount of your money on.

I don't think i've ever been so disappointed by a movie. I loved the TV show as a child and i was so excited to see this movie. With the exception of Bill Paxton all the actors are perfectly cast and nail the characters, but the script fails and tries to follow the Spy Kids formula which doesn't work with Thunderbirds. Many plot elements don't add up (Why is International Rescus so public? Aren't they supposed to be secret?)

The best sequences in the movie are the CGI parts. The look of Thunderbirds is definetly present and i love the recreation of the Thunderbird vechicles. But the heart of the original (along with many of the plot elements) is missing and the film is definetly a missed oppurtunity.

When is Hollywood going to get that nothing good comes out of making a movie from very old kid shows? I mean, movies like Flinstones who was nothing put a failure and i am not even going to mention the horrific sequel. Scooby Doo is maybe the best of the worst but still something that should have been avoided at all cost, and many many more. For a second i was expecting something exiting, entertaining, lively and fun like for example Spy Kids (which i think is a very good family movie) but unfortunately i got the opposite.

Thunderbirds is a thin, extinct children's movie that has nothing good to offer the people over 11 and specially not the parents. Bill Paxton and Ben Kingsley are both class A actors but unfortunately they are given roles of unexciting stereotypes and I don't doubt this movie put a black stain on their record. The kids are just awful, the acting reminds me of a Disney show that has run its course. Couldn't they have spent a little more time on casting and a little less on the visuals? All of them are irritating and plain boring. The movie may have cool visual effects like a Hollywood movie is made to do but the movie never becomes anywhere near mediocre. 

I can imagine the young children under 11 enjoying this but even then it's pretty limited but the rest of us will be checking our clocks every 2 minutes.

2/10 -- Disappointing to say the least.
Come on..it's thunderbirds..and boy does it fail....badly...still CGi is good...

I saw this movie when I was 8 years old with my camp. "Thunderbirds" was pretty damn lame. The acting was a joke, there is barely even any action, and the whole concept in turning the show (which I have not seen, but looks good) into a movie was just plain ridiculous.

This takes place next year. The plot involves a teenager named Alan Tracy who is determined to become a Thunderbird. But when the evil Hood and kidnaps most his family, it's up to little Alan and his friends to save the day.

So, yeah, this movie did suck, but I've seen far worse than this (Catwoman, anyone?). For those interested in seeing the Thunderbirds, watch the TV show instead, and not this movie. "Thunderbirds" the movie will quickly put you to sleep.

Final Score: 30/100 (Pretty lame)

Ok to begin with I just want to say that some films should never be made.....This is one of them! So how to describe this dreary, actionless, and utterly boring movie? One word........Stupid! When I spent √Ç¬£6 of my hard earned cash I was expecting (as a huge Thunderbirds and Gerry Anderson fan) to be blown away. The designs and set pieces in the photos looked fantastic! I was bitterly disappointed with the 91 minute farce I had to endure! From start to finish I was presented with bad actors who didn't really seem to understand what they were doing, they had no talent and I just felt that something I was excited about was dying on its arse! Okay some people tried, Ben Kingsley was good but he mainly acted like a pantomime villain, all that was missing was a moustache for easy twirling! I almost wanted to boo and hiss! Mind you by the end of the film I wanted to boo and hiss at the entire film! This film only has 1 and a half stars because of its lavish design but the rest just doesn't deserve credit! In my opinion Jonathan Frakes has a lot to answer for!

THUNDERBIRDS ARE GO!

'Jeff Tracy: Thunderbirds are go!'
'Alan Tracy: Hey, Dad. That stuff the Hood said, about you leaving him to die. He was lying, right? 
Jeff Tracy: No. See, you can't save everyone, Alan. It doesn't matter how hard you try or how brave you are. It doesn't even matter if it's someone you love, someone you'd give your life in a second to save. You just can't save everyone.'
'Fermat: [Alan wants to use the Thunderizer to escape] But Alan, this equipment is only to be used in case of an emergency! 
[Tintin and Alan look at him] 
Fermat: I guess this qualifies!'
'Fermat: Just because I s.s.stutter, doesn't mean that I'm wrong. If we're a team, we should make decisions as a team!'
'The Hood: Who will rescue the rescuers?'

Against my better judgement I watched this film again as we had just finished going through the Thunderbirds series on blu-ray. 

I still believe that this film is an appalling attempt at a 21st century take on Thunderbirds and an insult to Gerry Anderson's legacy. Perhaps it's good for kids, but I think they missed the main audience who would have loved this film. The only good thing was the modernised Thunderbird machines (except that fugly FAB1 Rolls Royce turned Ford/Hydrofoil/Plane). 

Thunderbirds never centered around one person in particular, but that's what this movie does. The producers turned it into a kids film. They focussed on children, added another child that was never in the series and made the Thunderbirds look like play-toys, right down to the seats, controls and computer read outs. The 'goons' were stupid and unfunny, the fight sequences were overdone with silly sound effects and the distinctive parts of certain characters, like Brains were over-exaggerated to the point of annoyance.

0.5 of a star for the special effects, which by 2011 standards are looking dated as well. I'll save the remaining 4.5 stars for when someone does Thunderbirds proper justice on the big screen...

If you make a live action version it loses it's one source of appeal and becomes just another B rate action movie. Dumba$$es!

I was a huge Thunderbirds fan as a kid, and this was the movie that my dad and I had been waiting to get made for years. Am now wondering if we coud have waited just bit longer

Rather than go into a full review of the movie I thought I would point out the things they got right and the things they got wrong

What they got Right:
- Lady Penelope and Parker - I thought the actors that portrayed them did a fantastic job, got the characters down pat
- Ben Kingsley was good as The Hood, menacing yet funny, much like the series
- The Thunderbirds Machines - modernised, yet faithful to the original, plus with a good sound system these things (especially T2) will shake the room
- Casting of The Tracy family was fairly shoddy, but I thought they played the characters ok. Brady Corbet who plays Alan played him quite good, only thing being his downfall is that he is one of those guys you just want to beat up
- The Music - the famous countdown is there (there would have been blood on the street if it wasnt), but that song by Busted that plays in the credits is awesome, that song alone improved the entire movie

What they got wrong:
- A lot
- Aimed at kids - considering those that loved the show as a kid would have to be at an average age of 40 why would you make it a kids movie? They should have gone the Spiderman route - aim it at adults, the kids will still love it
- No rolls royce - fair enough on the producers, rolls royce wouldnt let them use the name, so they went the obvious 2nd choice - A Ford Thunderbird - which looked quite cool I must say, but why oh why was there a ford logo in nearly every shot? WAY TOO MUCH ADVERTISING!!!! For a moment i thought the thunderbird machines were gonna have Ford logos on them!
- The cast in general was shocking, a few notable exceptions (see above). They should have got someone with a bit more notoriety than Bill Paxton, nothing against Bill, i think he's a great actor, but someone a bit older would have been better, in fact the Tracy family in general was way to young.
- Big problems with that Fermat guy, whoever thought of him should be severly punished, he is without a doubt the biggest problem with this movie, if they wanted young heros they should have stuck with Tin Tin and Alan.
- Small problem - Brains' stutter is completely stuffed, he sounds like a retard instead of a genius, they should have kept the same stutter that they had in the series (if that makes sense)

There is a million other pros and cons about this movie, but I havent got the time or patience to write all of them.

In summary, Thunderbirds is an OK movie for kids, and would be a good way to introduce the series to a new generation, but for the true fans it is a let down

I hope they do a Batman/James Bond and do another film in which this one is completely forgotten about, because it has the potential to be great and Im sure the fans will still want to see it.

01.07.09
6th Film of 2009

Right, now that the spurt of new films is finished i can go back to reviewing the films i want to review and not the ones i simply feel obligated to. Now i actually gave this half a star but then smashed a lightbulb over my face to wake myself up, it will never deserve such a high rating.


There are a million and one things wrong with this movie and if your planning on seeing it anytime soon, i'd suggest a nice trip to death row instead as it will be alot less painful.


I grew up on the thunderbirds, as did alot of my friends, as did alot of my friends parents so naturally from the awsome teaser trailer i was rather excited. But after seeing it; self-harm never seemed so desirable. Now, a thunderbirds movie, you'd expect would contain one key feature: the thunderbirds. This however was thought unnessercary by the director in favour of 3 rejects from high school musical that nobody cares about. Somehow they can drive the thunderbirds too, hmmm. Who the fuck is alan tracy anyway? wasnt he thunderbird 3's driver? Nope, not anymore. He's an emotionless plank of a child actor who is likely to be assasinated if he is to utter the word 'narley!' one more time. 


The girl with him isnt even hot and the other kid looks like the nerdy one from Honey i shrunk the kids. Basically, there is nothing right with this film. Its as if the writer took everything that was thunderbirds and not only shitted on it, but then ate it all up only to shit on it again and again. 


If there is a sequel, it will be presented to us by the four horsemen of the apocalypse as keys to the rapture. But just when you thought you had seen the worst of it, and the credits start to roll; the true horrors of this film are presented to us.


Yes, its everybodys favorite wannabe rockstars Busted singing another holocaust anthem this time about everyones former favorite TV show. 


I recall the line from the song 'Aint it cool when spaceships come out the pool'. Now this line sums up how this film was made for me. 100% of the population who watched this show loved it, 80% of those people had the toys and 40% of those had their very own model tracey island and so will know that thunderbird one comes out of the pool and is indeed NOT a spaceship, they are clearly mistaking it for thunderbird 3 which IS a spaceship and comes out of a nearby launch pad. Now this may seem like the nerdiest thing you've ever heard but to the ageing fans of the series is a damn right travisty!

The fans of the show were young then and are now older, this film should have been aimed at a more mature age group as it doesnt relate to the youth now as it did back then. Although thinking about it, this film would have been just as shit if it had been released when i was a kid. I would have shitted myself just so i could dip the VHS tape into my nappy before smashing it with my metal optimus prime doll.


Harsh i know, but very very fair.

I was so disappointed with this film the first time around that I didn't even finish watching it, but I figured I couldn't write a fair review unless I witnessed the entire atrocity. As far as kids movies go, it is cute and works. However, this film was meant to be an updated remake of a cult classic British show that spawned two films... and it fails in all but the most basic ways. First of all, Thunderbirds referred to the vehicles not necessarily the Tracys who were member of International Rescue, which is never spoken in this version although it does appear at least twice. Also, the ages of the Tracy brothers and their relationships with Lady Penelope and Tin Tin were altered to fit the kid film mold. If you're a fan of the Thunderbirds of old, pass on this sad attempt at a revival...
its pretty good, its a lot like a comic book

Tellement le meilleur film que j'ai vu !! J'ai tellement aime ce film :O !!

THUNDERBIRDS

Almost forty years after the original TV series was produced, Hollywood has decided to resurrect Gerry Anderson?s ¬´ Thunderbirds ¬ª, or rather, to ¬´ fleshify ¬ª them, Pinocchio-like, by replacing them with ¬´ live ¬ª actors (many of whom look slightly less alive than the original puppets.) Quite bizarrely, though, the only purpose for this belated incarnation seems to have been to get the cult characters out of the way as soon as the plot gets started only to bring them back in the last ten minutes to applaud the actual heroes of the movie, three teens aged 13 to 16 who ¬´ save the day ¬ª despite their age and inexperience, and whose adventures constitute the film itself, which looks like (and may well be, so far as I know) a long advertisement for rides in a Tracy Island theme park produced for some teleshopping  channel.

All is not absolutely worthless in the movie. I liked Ron Cook as Parker and Sophia Myles as Lady Penelope, though I think she erred a bit on the Barbie side (both of them are familiar faces to fans of BBC period dramas), and Ben Kingsley seems to have had a great time aiming his broad acting at pre-teens. But I was particularly disgusted at the hijacking of the original concept for the Spy Kids generation, and the fact that the cult puppet show has been turned into a ¬´ hair movie ¬ª, i.e. one of those films in which it is very hard to focus on the actors? faces because your gaze is constantly distracted upwards by the silly, improbable architectures of hair and gel that have been put up on their heads by what must have been at least half of the film crew.
